title: Glacier Bay National Park & Preserve: Glacier Bay Plant Succession
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Nature     Plants     Glacier Bay Plant Succession                Plant Succession in Pictures                                The Return of Life Take a "journey through time" with Ranger Jeff to see how plant life returns to the barren landscapes left behind by retreating glaciers.  Duration:3 minutes, 30 seconds                  It's not much to look at but moss like this will start to colonize glacial till, paving the way for the plants that follow.         The seeds of fireweed are perfectly designed to be carried to new areas by the wind.         Dryas (shown gone to seed) is very good at enriching the soil with nitrogen, something all plants need to live. Notice the moss growing close to the ground around the dryas mat and the cottonwood trees growing up in the middle.         Alder is good at fixing nitrogen in the soil. But it can make hiking very difficult, if not impossible!         Eventually, spruce trees begin to grow under the alder thicket.         Hemlock trees are an important member of the mature forest community.         A mature spruce and hemlock forest (often referred to as "old growth") is a lovely yet disorderly place, with trees at all stages of growth and decay.                   Glacier Bay Plant Photos   20 Photos  Enjoy the colorful plant life that thrives in our coastal temperate rainforest.
